title: 113_hr1768
content: The Act may be cited as the "Accountability Review Board Reform Act of 2013". The Accountability Review Board process was established by Congress in 1986 to assess security-related incidents at US Government missions abroad, promote security measures, and ensure accountability of personnel. The Accountability Review Board process was established by Congress in 1986 to assess security-related incidents at US Government missions abroad. The terrorist attack in Benghazi, Libya, on September 11, 2012, that resulted in the deaths of four US Government personnel has highlighted the need to increase the independence of these Boards from the Department of State. The Accountability Review Board process was established by Congress in 1986 to assess security incidents at US Government missions abroad. The need to increase the independence of these Boards from the Department of State was highlighted after the terrorist attack in Benghazi, Libya, on September 11, 2012. SEC. 3 requires notification to Congress about certain information related to these Boards. Subsection (c) of section 301 of the Omnibus Diplomatic Security and Antiterrorism Act is amended to include additional individuals who can assist the Accountability Review Board in carrying out its duties. This amendment adds requirements for reporting on the employment of certain individuals to aid the Board. The Omnibus Diplomatic Security and Antiterrorism Act is amended to specify the membership of a Board, with five members appointed by different authorities. Non-Federal members will be paid at a specified rate for their service. The Omnibus Diplomatic Security and Antiterrorism Act specifies the membership of a Board with five members appointed by different authorities. Members engaged in duties receive no additional pay if they are Federal officers or employees. Boards can hire staff and have Federal Government employees assist without interruption. The Omnibus Diplomatic Security and Antiterrorism Act allows Boards to hire staff and have Federal Government employees assist without interruption. Individuals assisting the Board must adhere to conflict of interest rules. The Omnibus Diplomatic Security and Antiterrorism Act prohibits the appointment of individuals with conflicts of interest to Boards. Individuals must decline appointment if they have knowledge of a conflict of interest. The Omnibus Diplomatic Security and Antiterrorism Act prohibits individuals with conflicts of interest from serving on Boards. Members must recuse themselves from activities involving individuals with whom they have a conflict of interest, defined as a non-routine financial relationship. The Omnibus Diplomatic Security and Antiterrorism Act prohibits conflicts of interest on Boards, requiring recusal from activities involving non-routine financial relationships, familial or close personal relationships, and direct workplace relationships. SEC. 5. EVIDENCE. Amends section 303 of the Omnibus Diplomatic Security and Antiterrorism Act to allow the Board to accept evidence deemed relevant by a member, without being bound by Federal Rules of Evidence. SEC. 6. BOARD ACTIONS. The Omnibus Diplomatic Security and Antiterrorism Act is amended to require Boards to submit findings and recommendations to improve security and efficiency of reviewed programs within 90 days, with a possible 60-day extension if needed. The Omnibus Diplomatic Security and Antiterrorism Act now allows for a 60-day extension if additional time is needed for a thorough review of programs. Members can submit dissenting views, and the Secretary of State must report on actions taken within 90 days of receiving recommendations from the Board. The Secretary of State will update regulations to implement the amendments. The amendments will apply to Accountability Review Boards convened after the enactment of the Act.
